issues.title: Privacy isn't enough
issues.author: mallory
issues.body: Danielle Citron has written about how a privacy-only approach to technology ends up benefiting those who are powerful and so in the introduction text we might elaborate why the privacy-first conceptual framework needs to shift in the case of IPV considerations.

issues.title: Notification systems
issues.author: claucece
issues.body:
John Curran notes:

"""
    This is a most excellent document - thanks for all your work on it!

    Regarding the Recommendation section, I note that the document doesn’t include any mention of importance of the notification capabilities of authentication systems as a means for mitigation possible abuser use of technology. 

    As means of example, I’d refer to the work of the National Network to End Domestic Violence (NNEDV) and Facebook in making clear possible mitigations to technology by abusers, and their publication "A guide for Survivors of Abuse” <https://nnedv.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/Library_TH_2018_Privacy_Safety_Facebook_Guide_Survivors_Abuse.pdf>, which calls out the usefulness of notifications in detecting misuse of technology by abusers - 

>     Login notifications
>
>     You can be notified, either by email or text message, if someone tries to access your account from a computer or device that you haven’t used before.
>
>     Login approvals
>
>     If you are logging into your account from a different web browser or device, you must have a security code to access your account.
>
>     Recognized devices
>
>     You can manage the devices that are allowed to have access to your account and be notified if an unknown device tries to access your account. This is particularly helpful for a survivor who may have wanted to access their account from their partner’s device, but now no longer wants that device to have access.
>
>     Active sessions
>
>     This is important to note because it shows sessions that are currently active or logged on. You may have active sessions if you’ve accessed your account or are using an app and forgot to log off. This also will show if someone else might have accessed your account. In that case, you can choose to ‘End Activity,’ which will block that device from continuing to access your account.

    This usefulness of such controls echoed in another recent paper "A Domestic Violence Dystopia: Abuse via the Internet of Things and Remedies Under Current Law” <https://californialawreview.org/print/a-domestic-violence-dystopia-abuse-via-the-internet-of-things-and-remedies-under-current-law/#clr-toc-heading-10>. which notes implications of technology design on those facing potential abuse – "Safe design should also include automatic generation of weekly or monthly reports informing users about their data and account logins, a system notification that shows which registered user initiated the controls, and the standard of requiring that users opt into rather than out of data-sharing between members of a household. “

    I’d encourage some further discussion on the list of the notification aspects of authentication systems and their potential use in mitigation of abuse via technology, and if found useful, inclusion of additional text in the authentication systems portion of the recommendations.

comments.author: claucece
comments.body: Seems good to add them to the recommendations section.

issues.title: Gaslighting
issues.author: claucece
issues.body:
Leonie notes:

```
I wondered if it may also be helpful to emphasise “gaslighting” in the text explicitly (fits under “perception of threat”). I am
 saying this because both the over- and underestimation of a device’s capabilities can be misused (we highlighted this in a
 recent report for the UK Government): https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/978692/The_UK_code_of_practice_for_consumer_IoT_security_-_PETRAS_UCL_research_report.pdf. 
```

comments.author: julianaguerra
comments.body:
Maybe we should replace the category "perception of threat" by "gaslighting" as the tactic (or the threat) is not the perception itself but the intended manipulation and control (by the perpetrator) of the victim's perceptions of reality.

The document referenced by Leonie is focused on IoT devices but the main point on gaslighting, I think, is how it is "effective when it is rooted in social inequalities, especially gender and sexuality, and executed in power-laden intimate relationships" (Sweet, 2019).

Another option is adding the category of "gaslighting" separated from "perception of threat", with a wording similar to 

Gaslighting: by taking control of smartphones or IoT devices, the attacker is able to manipulate the victim's perception of reality and making them feel they are insane. This power is rooted in inequalities and different digital gaps.

comments.author: claucece
comments.body:
@julianaguerra yes! 

Might be good to:
1. Expand the section on perception of threats. 
2. Add how it relates to gaslighting and define it.

issues.title: OGBV citation
issues.author: mallory
issues.body:
Quotable text from https://www.apc.org/sites/default/files/gender-cybersecurity-policy-litreview.pdf:

"Women and girls face specific cyber threats in the digital age that are considered forms of gender-based violence as they occur because of their gender, or because they disproportionately affect one gender. While this violence is mediated by digital technology, it is part of the same offline structural violence; but its technological dimension adds elements of search, persistence, replicability and scalability that facilitate the aggressors’ access to their targets and can exacerbate the harm."

issues.title: ICRW citation
issues.author: mallory
issues.body:
Useful citation: https://www.icrw.org/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/ICRW_TFGBVMarketing_Brief_v8-Web.pdf.
Main points to:
 * integrate into the introduction on "a spectrum of behaviors, including stalking, bullying, sexual harassment, defamation, hate speech and exploitation."
 * Introduction text answers the call to "Technology companies can design or adapt solutions to mitigate the pervasiveness and impacts of technology-facilitated GBV among users;" (there is also a call to researchers).
 * And in the abstract we might consider this work to be a rare opportunity for prevention of tech-assisted GBV.
 * Could also check lists of tactics and "modes".

issues.title: Better linkage between problems and solutions
issues.author: elear
issues.body:
The mitigations listed in Section 5 don't link to the attacks that are mentioned.  This makes it difficult to understand what sort of risks remain if an engineer followed all the advice given.  That is, given a particular attack, what is the particular mitigation?  This is the strategy recommended by RFC 3552, and I think we are wise to follow it here, if necessary with an explanation or references as to why various mitigations are important in that case.  I would presume that a number of the mitigations overlap.

BTW, I'm not suggesting that you delete Section 5.  It can serve as a reasonable summary, and you might even create a table to indicate which mitigations address which attacks.  But neither a table nor a summary are enough to demonstrate appropriate remediation.  Some support is required, if for no other reason, than for us to recognize when there is a potential workaround by the attacker to the remediation
